sen.e: Besides the Shinto priesthood, fukuotoko (the luckiest man), fukumusume (a good fortune girl), people involved in Shinto rituals (such as an arrow picker of a bow and arrow performance at a festival), and performers and promoters at a festival (including sumo wrestlers, street performers of a lion dance with jugglery called daikagura, and stall keepers at a fair) as well as their sources (such as sarugaku (form of theater popular in Japan during the 11th to 14th centuries), a puppet show called kugutsu) are all 'kannagi', and they have been thought to have special power to bring good lucks.

sen.j: 日本には森羅万象のものに対し神や魂が宿るという考え方から、多くのものや事柄に対し「畏怖や畏敬の念を抱く」という考え方があり、またそれは、物に対する感謝や、物を大事にする・大事に使う・大事に利用する（食する）という考えにつながり、様々なものを依り代として祀ってきた。
sen.e: In Japan, the concept that gods or souls should reside in all things in nature led people to have a feeling of 'awe and respect' about many things and matters, which also made them have gratitude to things and attitudes of taking good care of things, using and eating things with care, and as a result they enshrined various things as a yorishiro.

sen.e: Artificial mounds (excluding ant mounds and dunghills) were made to prevent gods residing in various creatures and tools from becoming violent gods and to enshrine them so that they would become kannagi (a peaceful god) and bring happiness (some artificial mounds except for ancient tombs are objects of worship).

sen.j: 具体的な例としては、人形塚・包丁塚・道具塚などの人工ものや、鯨塚や魚塚といった生き物、または、戦乱や災害や不幸や事件で無くなった人やその遺品の塚として、蒙古塚・首塚・刀塚などがる。
